title: 114_hr380
content: The Medicare Identity Theft Prevention Act of 2015 prohibits the inclusion of Social Security account numbers on Medicare cards. The Medicare Identity Theft Prevention Act of 2015 prohibits displaying Social Security numbers on Medicare cards, requiring cost-effective procedures to ensure compliance. The Medicare Identity Theft Prevention Act of 2015 mandates the removal of Social Security numbers from Medicare cards, with the Secretary of Health and Human Services tasked to establish a cost-effective process for compliance, including providing assistance to beneficiaries and healthcare providers. The Medicare Identity Theft Prevention Act of 2015 requires the removal of Social Security numbers from Medicare cards. A process should be implemented to use a Medicare beneficiary identifier that is not a Social Security number externally, but can be converted to a Social Security number for internal use by the Department of Health and Human Services and the Social Security Administration. Funding for implementation will come from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. The Medicare Identity Theft Prevention Act of 2015 mandates the removal of Social Security numbers from Medicare cards. Funding for implementation will be sourced from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. Transfers of specified amounts to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Program Management Account and the Social Security Administration Limitation on Administration Account are outlined for fiscal years 2015 to 2018. For fiscal years 2016 and 2017, $22,000,000 is allocated until 2018. In fiscal year 2018, $27,000,000 is available indefinitely. The Railroad Retirement Board Limitation on Administration Account receives $3,000,000 for fiscal year 2015. The effective date for the removal of Social Security numbers from Medicare cards is within four years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will reissue Medicare cards that comply with new requirements within four years of the Act's effective date.
